TITLE: Historic climate bill to supercharge clean energy industry
SUMMARY: The climate and energy provisions of Democrats' Inflation Reduction Act would speed greenhouse gas cuts and put the U.S. on track to deliver the lion's share of President Biden's target for 2030.

TITLE: Republican push to overturn Biden permitting rules passes Senate, with Manchin's support
SUMMARY: The resolution is unlikely to pass the House, where Democrats hold a slightly larger majority, and President Joe Biden is also expected to veto the measure if it makes it to his desk.

TITLE: Kentucky governor: ‘Hundreds’ of people are unaccounted for
‘We’re going to be finding bodies for weeks,’ Kentucky governor says of floods
SUMMARY: Gov. Andy Beshear provided a grim update on the impact of the extreme weather and floods the state has been hammered with in recent days.

TITLE: The Manchin pressure campaign: CEOs, labor bosses and Bill Gates
SUMMARY: The people involved who spoke with POLITICO described an effort with multiple entry points.

TITLE: 'Easter eggs' in climate bill delight oil and gas industry
SUMMARY: "If you squint hard enough, you can see this being a bipartisan compromise," one lobbyist said.

TITLE: What's in the Democrats' climate and energy legislation
SUMMARY: The bill, dubbed the “Inflation Reduction Act of 2022,” would spend nearly $370 billion on a raft of tax credits to help stimulate adoption of clean energy technologies.

TITLE: Falling gas prices blunt Republican campaign attacks
SUMMARY: For now, the decrease in energy prices may offer Democrats a respite from GOP attack ads on inflation.

TITLE: ‘Holy s--t’: Surprise Senate deal sets stage for record climate change package
SUMMARY: An aggressive effort to sway Sen. Joe Manchin managed to salvage a package that its authors say will help drive sharp cuts in greenhouse gases.

TITLE: Biden launches plan to bring solar to low-income homes
SUMMARY: The Biden administration projects the program could spur the development of 134 gigawatts of new solar power capacity nationwide.

TITLE: Why expensive gasoline is here to stay
SUMMARY: "Future presidents and administrations are going to be absolutely bedeviled by high gasoline prices."

TITLE: Average U.S. gasoline price falls 32 cents
SUMMARY: The average price at the pump is still $1.32 higher than it was one year ago.

TITLE: Al Gore compares ‘climate deniers’ to Uvalde police officers
SUMMARY: “They heard the screams, they heard the gunshots, and nobody stepped forward,” he said of law enforcement at the Texas school shooting.

TITLE: 'Dead bodies' and dump sites draw DOJ civil rights probe of Houston
SUMMARY: The northeast Houston area in question has suffered for years from the dumping of trash that poses health and quality of life risks.

TITLE: Declaring a climate emergency could unlock potent tools for Biden — at a steep cost
SUMMARY: Many of Biden’s supporters in Congress are urging him to go bold nonetheless.

TITLE: Biden announces modest steps to fight climate's ‘clear and present danger’
SUMMARY: Setbacks in Congress and at the Supreme Court are putting President Joe Biden's climate change goals out of reach as brutal heatwaves descend on much of the U.S. and Europe.

TITLE: Impact of Supreme Court's climate ruling spreads
SUMMARY: The legal doctrine that the conservative justices used to strike down an EPA regulation in late June is popping up in a host of new legal challenges — including many having nothing to do with climate change.

TITLE: Biden to announce small steps as climate agenda stalls
SUMMARY: Biden is stopping short of acceding to pleas from progressive activists to declare a climate emergency.

TITLE: Biden to announce climate actions but not yet declare an ‘emergency’
SUMMARY: Lawmakers said the White House has informed them it was considering the emergency declaration, though it had not yet decided whether to take the step.

TITLE: Manchin's climate rebuff adds to Congress' troubled track record
SUMMARY: The collapse of what would have been the biggest climate-related spending measures in U.S. history is the latest failure by Congress.

TITLE: Canadian lawmakers will be called to explain return of Nord Stream turbines
SUMMARY: House committee votes to probe the decision that one Conservative MP called 'a slap in the face to the Ukrainian people.'

TITLE: Biden's quiet campaign to bring Saudi Arabia around on climate
SUMMARY: The effort reflects delicate diplomacy as the U.S. attempts to mend ties with Saudi Arabia.

TITLE: Democrats, climate activists grasp for comeback after blow from Manchin
SUMMARY: The United States, the world's No. 2 producer of greenhouse gas pollution, may find itself with little ability to address the problem.

TITLE: Manchin disputes claims he rejected Dems’ climate and energy spending
SUMMARY: "As far as I'm concerned, I want climate, I want an energy policy."

TITLE: Don’t expect Biden’s Saudi trip to bring down oil prices
SUMMARY: A hard push by the president would probably fail to get Saudi leaders to pump new crude supplies into the world oil market.

TITLE: Biden’s other green promise
SUMMARY: The president has vowed to protect poor communities from bearing an unfair burden of air and water pollution. To do it will require reversing decades of industry-friendly regulations.

TITLE: Interior offshore oil drilling plan skirts tough choices
SUMMARY: The plan from the Interior Department was released just one day after the Supreme Court issued a ruling sharply limiting EPA's power to curb pollution causing climate change.

TITLE: 'We don’t have to pretend anymore': Greens ready to bail on D.C.
SUMMARY: Environmentalists and many of their Democratic allies are preparing to focus on state capitals as the places to press for action on climate change — going back to a strategy they employed during the Trump era.

TITLE: Why Biden's climate push might not be doomed
SUMMARY: It wouldn't be easy, but Democrats could still look to Congress, other kinds of regulations or the states in their effort to cut greenhouse gases.

TITLE: ‘Shocking’ and ‘disgraceful’: Supreme Court climate ruling sparks anger from Democrats, environmentalists
SUMMARY: “Climate change is here and happening regardless of whether a tiny, extremist minority wants us to do something about it,” a White House official said.
